nealrichardson commented on pull request #4401: ARROW-5416: [Website] Add Homebrew to project installation page
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4401#discussion_r288608145
 
 

 ##########
 File path: site/install.md
 ##########
 @@ -69,6 +69,15 @@ in `requirements.txt` to install the latest patch release.
 These include the Apache Arrow and Apache Parquet C++ binary libraries bundled
 with the wheel.
 
+### C++ Library on Homebrew (macOS)
 
 Review comment:
   Done, along with the other requested changes, PTAL.
   
   Why are these "unofficial"? Aren't they built from the 0.13.0 release that was voted on? How are the Python wheels "official" and these aren't? How can we make all of our packages official?
   
   I get that this may be an important distinction within the Apache community, but to people who aren't familiar with what that means, it sounds like we're raising doubts about the quality of our own software. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on pull request #4401: ARROW-5416: [Website] Add Homebrew to project installation page
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4401#discussion_r288624387
 
 

 ##########
 File path: site/install.md
 ##########
 @@ -69,6 +69,15 @@ in `requirements.txt` to install the latest patch release.
 These include the Apache Arrow and Apache Parquet C++ binary libraries bundled
 with the wheel.
 
+### C++ Library on Homebrew (macOS)
 
 Review comment:
   @nealrichardson it's an Apache process thing. We can't call a package "official" unless 
   
   * It is a source package voted on by the PMC
   * It is a binary artifact voted on by the PMC
   * It is a built locally from an official source tarball
   
   If the Homebrew packages are built locally from the official source tarball then I don't think they need to be marked unofficial. I think HB caches some binaries of things so if those are being installed then we can't call them official
   
   On the installation page we should add a section to clarify what is meant by "unofficial"
   
   For the record nearly all Spark and Hadoop-related builds used in production are produced by vendors and are not official ASF releases, so this is already the norm
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

nealrichardson commented on pull request #4401: ARROW-5416: [Website] Add Homebrew to project installation page
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4401#discussion_r288662363
 
 

 ##########
 File path: site/install.md
 ##########
 @@ -69,6 +69,15 @@ in `requirements.txt` to install the latest patch release.
 These include the Apache Arrow and Apache Parquet C++ binary libraries bundled
 with the wheel.
 
+### C++ Library on Homebrew (macOS)
 
 Review comment:
   FWIW the words "official" and "unofficial" don't appear on either http://spark.apache.org/downloads.html or https://hadoop.apache.org/releases.html. https://wiki.apache.org/hadoop/Distributions%20and%20Commercial%20Support?action=show&redirect=Distribution has a couple of sentences about what defines "a release of Apache Hadoop" that might be a good reference for us.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on pull request #4401: ARROW-5416: [Website] Add Homebrew to project installation page
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4401#discussion_r288735385
 
 

 ##########
 File path: site/install.md
 ##########
 @@ -69,6 +69,15 @@ in `requirements.txt` to install the latest patch release.
 These include the Apache Arrow and Apache Parquet C++ binary libraries bundled
 with the wheel.
 
+### C++ Library on Homebrew (macOS)
 
 Review comment:
   Right, Spark and Hadoop are pretty different projects in terms of how they are installed and deployed in production compared with our C++ and Python binaries. It's a semantic / language issue but we are unable to call any artifact that we haven't voted on a "release", so we either have to have a clear delineation between official/unofficial or not list the not-voted-on artifacts at all
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

users@infra.apache.org

kou commented on pull request #4401: ARROW-5416: [Website] Add Homebrew to project installation page
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4401#discussion_r288771935
 
 

 ##########
 File path: site/install.md
 ##########
 @@ -69,6 +69,15 @@ in `requirements.txt` to install the latest patch release.
 These include the Apache Arrow and Apache Parquet C++ binary libraries bundled
 with the wheel.
 
+### C++ Library on Homebrew (macOS)
 
 Review comment:
   Normally, Homebrew users install Homebrew formulas as "bottle" rather than build locally from source. "Bottle" is a binary package: https://docs.brew.sh/Bottles
   
   If "bottle" is available for the formula, Homebrew uses "bottle" by default. So I think that "unofficial" is suitable for Homebrew.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
